intro: Rubus bifrons var. cinerascens, commonly known as the silverleaf blackberry, is a variant of the blackberry plant characterized by its distinctive silvery-gray undersides on its leaves. It is native to the western United States, particularly in California and Oregon, where it thrives in coastal and chaparral habitats. The plant produces small, dark purple to black berries that are typically harvested in late summer. Its leaves are palmately lobed and have a leathery texture, while the stems are covered in fine, white hairs. This variety is valued for its ornamental appeal and is also used in local ecosystems as a food source for wildlife.
